thread.title_full: Newcrest CEO pay still 'excessive' but investors told to avoid second strike | afr.com

author: Peter Ker
title: Newcrest CEO pay still 'excessive' but investors told to avoid second strike
text:
The remuneration package awarded to Newcrest Mining chief executive Sandeep Biswas may prove less contentious than at last year's AGM Arsineh Houspian Share on twitter by Peter Ker Newcrest Mining shareholders have been told to avoid spilling the board of the gold miner at next week's annual general meeting, even though influential advisers say chief executive Sandeep Biswas's remuneration package remains "excessive".
Newcrest goes into the meeting on "one strike" after more than 44 per cent of shareholders opposed its remuneration report in 2014.
Under corporations law, a motion to spill the board can be heard if at least 25 per cent of shareholders vote against a company's remuneration report two years in a row, meaning the Newcrest board could be in trouble if 25 per cent reject the remuneration report next week.
Newcrest has sought to appease angry shareholders since last year's strike, and announced changes to its remuneration structure in August which will ensure that 50 per cent of short term incentives will be paid in shares rather than cash, the board has the ability to "clawback" previously awarded amounts if needed, and top executives will need to own a minimum number of shares in the company, among other changes.
Those changes have received crucial support in recent days from two of the proxy advisors that advocated for last year's strike.
Influential proxy advisory firms ISS Governance and CGI Glass Lewis have both urged shareholders to approve the remuneration report and avoid a spill of the board, with CGI saying such a move would not help the company.
"In our view, spilling the board of a company is an option of last resort," said CGI in a note to clients.
"We believe that the Company's remuneration policies are thoroughly explained and that its incentive plans are supportable. The Company's board should be commended for responding to the material shareholder concerns expressed at last year's AGM.
 "Furthermore, we note that the Company has also adequately aligned executive remuneration and company performance in the past year."
ISS said the Newcrest board had made enough changes to win back shareholder support.
"There has been concerted effort by the Company to address shareholder concerns by making improved disclosure and presenting clear metrics which align the company's financial performance with executive and shareholder outcomes. Accordingly, a board spill at this time is unlikely to be in shareholder's interest given the work undertaken by the company," said ISS in a note to clients.
Despite the proxy advisors' support for the remuneration report, the pay package awarded to Mr Biswas continues to raise eyebrows.
Mr Biswas earned $5.65 million in the year ended June 30, including superannuation benefits and performance bonuses.
About $2.25 million of that was guaranteed base salary, with Mr Biswas having one of the most generous base salaries in the mining industry.
Despite changes by Newcrest to ensure a greater amount of Mr Biswas's pay is "at risk" and his incentives are aligned with shareholder interests, ISS said the size of his package continues to be of concern.
"It is still not without concern that the quantum of total remuneration for the CEO remains substantial, if not considered by some shareholders as excessive," said ISS in the note.
Mr Biswas's fate is no doubt helped by the company's improved performance, which has been partly reflected by the 40 per cent share price rise in the past month.
Bloomberg lists contrarian fund manager Allan Gray as the fourth-biggest shareholder in Newcrest, and chief investment officer Simon Mawhinney said Allan Gray intended to support this year's remuneration report.
But Mr Mawhinney added he did not believe a spill of the board would be as disruptive as the proxy advisors had suggested, and he said a spill motion should proceed if shareholders give the gold miner a second strike.
Colonial First State Global Asset Management is another major holder of Newcrest shares, and its resources fund manager Todd Warren said last week that inflated pay packets were continuing to be an issue across the mining industry generally.
When asked if recent executive pay cuts at several big miners, including BHP Billiton, had eased shareholder concerns about excessive remuneration in the resources sector, Mr Warren said the debate was continuing to rage.
"Has the broader issue been fixed across the industry? That is a tough question, I think there continue to be issues, and the standard response is always that 'our pay is in line with our peers', which is a little bit trite," he said, when asked about the industry generally.
"It is obviously company specific but we have voted against some corporate pay packages where we felt the overall remuneration packages rewarded to executives were excessive, and we will continue to do so."
